channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: [Virtual Event] Shields Up: Key Technologies Reshaping Cybersecurity Defenses
Microsoft: Critical Windows Admin Center Flaw Allows Privilege Escalation
item.description: <p>A high-severity Windows Admin Center vulnerability (CVE-2026-26119) could allow privilege escalation in enterprise environments. Here’s what to know and how to mitigate risk.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-windows-admin-center-privilege-escalation-february-2026/">Microsoft: Critical Windows Admin Center Flaw Allows Privilege Escalation</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: Scam Abuses Gemini Chatbots to Convince People to Buy Fake Crypto
item.description: A convincing presale site for phony &quot;Google Coin&quot; features an AI assistant that engages victims with a slick sales pitch, funneling payment to attackers.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Critical Grandstream VoIP Bug Highlights SMB Security Blind Spot
item.description: CVE-2026-2329 allows unauthenticated root-level access to SMB phone infrastructure, so attackers can intercept calls, commit toll fraud, and impersonate users.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Dell's Hard-Coded Flaw: A Nation-State Goldmine
item.description: A China-related attacker has exploited the vendor flaw since mid-2024, allowing it to move laterally, maintain persistent access, and deploy malware.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: A CISO's Playbook for Defending Data Assets Against AI Scraping
item.description: Discover a strategic approach to govern scraping risks, balance security with business growth, and safeguard intellectual capital from automated data harvesting.
item.dc:creator: Areejit Banerjee

item.title: Citizen Lab Finds Cellebrite Tool Used on Kenyan Activist’s Phone in Police Custody
item.description: New research from the Citizen Lab has found signs that Kenyan authorities used a commercial forensic extraction tool manufactured by Israeli company Cellebrite to break into a prominent dissident's phone, making it the latest case of abuse of the technology targeting civil society. The interdisciplinary research unit at the University of Toronto's Munk School of Global Affairs &amp; Public
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Grandstream GXP1600 VoIP Phones Exposed to Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed a critical security flaw in the Grandstream GXP1600 series of VoIP phones that could allow an attacker to seize control of susceptible devices. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-2329, carries a CVSS score of 9.3 out of a maximum of 10.0. It has been described as a case of unauthenticated stack-based buffer overflow that could result in remote code
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Substack Breach May Have Leaked Nearly 700,000 User Details Online
item.description: <p>Substack says hackers accessed user emails, phone numbers, and internal metadata in October 2025, with a database of 697,313 records later posted online.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-substack-data-breach-user-accounts-leaked/">Substack Breach May Have Leaked Nearly 700,000 User Details Online</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Aminu Abdullahi

item.title: Cryptojacking Campaign Exploits Driver to Boost Monero Mining
item.description: Cryptojacking campaign used pirated software to deploy a persistent XMRig miner with stealth tactics

item.title: AI Assistants Used as Covert Command-and-Control Relays
item.description: AIs like Grok and Microsoft Copilot can be exploited as covert C2 channels for malware communication

item.title: Critical Flaws Found in Four VS Code Extensions with Over 125 Million Installs
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed multiple security vulnerabilities in four popular Microsoft Visual Studio Code (VS Code) extensions that, if successfully exploited, could allow threat actors to steal local files and execute code remotely. The extensions, which have been collectively installed more than 125 million times, are Live Server, Code Runner, Markdown Preview Enhanced, and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI Found Twelve New Vulnerabilities in OpenSSL
item.description: <p>The title of the post is&#8221;<a href="https://aisle.com/blog/what-ai-security-research-looks-like-when-it-works">What AI Security Research Looks Like When It Works</a>,&#8221; and I agree:</p> <blockquote><p>In the latest <a href="https://openssl-library.org/news/vulnerabilities/">OpenSSL security release&#62;</a> on January 27, 2026, twelve new zero-day vulnerabilities (meaning unknown to the maintainers at time of disclosure) were announced. Our AI system is responsible for the original discovery of all twelve, each found and responsibly disclosed to the OpenSSL team during the fall and winter of 2025. Of those, 10 were assigned CVE-2025 identifiers and 2 received CVE-2026 identifiers. Adding the 10 to the three we already found in the ...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Cybersecurity Tech Predictions for 2026: Operating in a World of Permanent Instability
item.description: In 2025, navigating the digital seas still felt like a matter of direction. Organizations charted routes, watched the horizon, and adjusted course to reach safe harbors of resilience, trust, and compliance. In 2026, the seas are no longer calm between storms. Cybersecurity now unfolds in a state of&nbsp;continuous atmospheric instability: AI-driven threats that adapt in real time, expanding
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Record Number of Ransomware Victims and Groups in 2025
item.description: Searchlight Cyber reports a 30% annual increase in ransomware victim numbers in 2025

item.title: Dell RecoverPoint for VMs Zero-Day CVE-2026-22769 Exploited Since Mid-2024
item.description: A maximum severity security vulnerability in Dell RecoverPoint for Virtual Machines has been exploited as a zero-day by a suspected China-nexus threat cluster dubbed UNC6201 since mid-2024, according to a new report from Google Mandiant and Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG). The activity involves the exploitation of CVE-2026-22769 (CVSS score: 10.0), a case of hard-coded credentials
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: 3 Ways to Start Your Intelligent Workflow Program
item.description: Security, IT, and engineering teams today are under relentless pressure to accelerate outcomes, cut operational drag, and unlock the full potential of AI and automation. But simply investing in tools isn’t enough. 88% of AI proofs-of-concept never make it to production, even though 70% of workers cite freeing time for high-value work as the primary AI automation motivation. Real impact comes
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Chinese APT Group Exploits Dell Zero-Day for Two Years
item.description: Mandiant reveals campaign featuring exploit of a CVSS 10.0 CVE in Dell RecoverPoint for Virtual Machines

item.title: Notepad++ Fixes Hijacked Update Mechanism Used to Deliver Targeted Malware
item.description: Notepad++ has released a security fix to plug gaps that were exploited by an advanced threat actor from China to hijack the software update mechanism to selectively deliver malware to targets of interest. The version 8.9.2 update incorporates what maintainer Don Ho calls a "double lock" design that aims to make the update process "robust and effectively unexploitable." This includes verification
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CISA Flags Four Security Flaws Under Active Exploitation in Latest KEV Update
item.description:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Tuesday added four security flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation in the wild. The list of vulnerabilities is as follows -
CVE-2026-2441 (CVSS score: 8.8) - A use-after-free vulnerability in Google Chrome that could allow a remote attacker to potentially exploit heap
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Singapore &amp; Its 4 Major Telcos Fend Off Chinese Hackers
item.description: After detecting a zero-day attack, the country's effective response was attributed to the tight relationship between its government and private industry.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Supply Chain Attack Embeds Malware in Android Devices
item.description: Keenadu downloads payloads that hijack browser searches, commit ad fraud, and execute other actions without user knowledge.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Poland Energy Survives Attack on Wind, Solar Infrastructure
item.description: Russia-aligned groups are probable culprits behind the wiper attacks against renewable energy farms, a manufacturer, and a heating and power plant.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: RMM Abuse Explodes as Hackers Ditch Malware
item.description: Remote monitoring and management (RMM) software offers hackers multiple benefits, including stealth, persistence, and operational efficiency.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: ClickFix Attacks Abuses DNS Lookup Command to Deliver ModeloRAT
item.description: ClickFix campaigns have adapted to the latest defenses with a new technique to trick users into infecting their own machines with malware.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Webinar: How Modern SOC Teams Use AI and Context to Investigate Cloud Breaches Faster
item.description: Cloud attacks move fast — faster than most incident response teams. In data centers, investigations had time. Teams could collect disk images, review logs, and build timelines over days. In the cloud, infrastructure is short-lived. A compromised instance can disappear in minutes. Identities rotate. Logs expire. Evidence can vanish before analysis even begins. Cloud forensics is fundamentally
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Researchers Show Copilot and Grok Can Be Abused as Malware C2 Proxies
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed that artificial intelligence (AI) assistants that support web browsing or URL fetching capabilities can be turned into stealthy command-and-control (C2) relays, a technique that could allow attackers to blend into legitimate enterprise communications and evade detection. The attack method, which has been demonstrated against Microsoft Copilot and xAI Grok
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: The AI Exchange: Innovators in Payment Security Featuring Bank of America
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: Keenadu Firmware Backdoor Infects Android Tablets via Signed OTA Updates
item.description: A new Android backdoor that's embedded deep into the device firmware can silently harvest data and remotely control its behavior, according to new findings from Kaspersky. The Russian cybersecurity vendor said it discovered the backdoor, dubbed Keenadu, in the firmware of devices associated with various brands, including Alldocube, with the compromise occurring during the firmware build phase.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Android 17 Beta Introduces Secure-By-Default Architecture
item.description: Android 17 Beta introduces privacy, security updates and a new Canary channel for improved development

item.title: Apple Expands RCS Encryption and Memory Protections in iOS 26.4
item.description: iOS 26.4 Beta adds end-to-end encryption for RCS messaging and enhanced Memory Integrity Enforcement

item.title: Low-Skilled Cybercriminals Use AI to Perform "Vibe Extortion" Attacks
item.description: Unit 42 researchers observed a low-skilled threat actor using an LLM to script a professional extortion strategy, complete with deadlines and pressure tactics

item.title: Over-Privileged AI Drives 4.5 Times Higher Incident Rates
item.description: Teleport study reveals that organizations running over-privileged AI have a 76% incident rate

item.title: Significant Rise in Ransomware Attacks Targeting Industrial Operations
item.description: Dragos annual report warns of a surge in ransomware attacks causing increased operational disruption in industrial environments

item.title: SmartLoader Attack Uses Trojanized Oura MCP Server to Deploy StealC Infostealer
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new SmartLoader campaign that involves distributing a trojanized version of a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server associated with Oura Health to deliver an information stealer known as StealC. "The threat actors cloned a legitimate Oura MCP Server – a tool that connects AI assistants to Oura Ring health data – and built a deceptive
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Side-Channel Attacks Against LLMs
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: My Day Getting My Hands Dirty with an NDR System
item.description: My objective As someone relatively inexperienced with network threat hunting, I wanted to get some hands-on experience using a network detection and response (NDR) system. My goal was to understand how NDR is used in hunting and incident response, and how it fits into the daily workflow of a Security Operations Center (SOC). Corelight’s Investigator software, part of its Open NDR Platform, is
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Is it OK to let your children post selfies online?
item.description: When it comes to our children’s digital lives, prohibition rarely works. It’s our responsibility to help them build a healthy relationship with tech.

item.title: Proofpoint Launches Proofpoint Partner Network to Accelerate Partner Growth and Profitability
Infostealer Targets OpenClaw to Loot Victim’s Digital Life
item.description: Hudson Rock has warned OpenClaw users that infostealers are targeting their configuration files

item.title: Microsoft Finds “Summarize with AI” Prompts Manipulating Chatbot Recommendations
item.description: New research from Microsoft has revealed that legitimate businesses are gaming artificial intelligence (AI) chatbots via the "Summarize with AI" button that's being increasingly placed on websites in ways that mirror classic search engine poisoning (SEO). The new AI hijacking technique has been codenamed AI Recommendation Poisoning by the Microsoft Defender Security Research Team. The tech giant
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: India’s Cybersecurity Cost Equation
item.description: <p>India’s cybersecurity budgets are rising, but SOC capacity isn’t keeping pace. Here’s how enterprises are measuring ROI and operational efficiency.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/tr-apac-india-cybersecurity-spend-capacity-gap/">India’s Cybersecurity Cost Equation</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Sasha Menon

item.title: Apple Tests End-to-End Encrypted RCS Messaging in iOS 26.4 Developer Beta
item.description: Apple on Monday released a new developer beta of iOS and iPadOS with support for end-to-end encryption (E2EE) in Rich Communications Services (RCS) messages. The feature is currently available for testing in iOS and iPadOS 26.4 Beta, and is expected to be shipped to customers in a future update for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, and watchOS. "End-to-end encryption is in beta and is not available for all
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Fake CAPTCHA Scam Tricks Windows Users Into Installing Malware
item.description: <p>A fake CAPTCHA scam is tricking Windows users into running PowerShell commands that install StealC malware and steal passwords, crypto wallets, and more.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-fake-captcha-scam-stealc-malware-windows/">Fake CAPTCHA Scam Tricks Windows Users Into Installing Malware</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: Infostealer Steals OpenClaw AI Agent Configuration Files and Gateway Tokens
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers disclosed they have detected a case of an information stealer infection successfully exfiltrating a victim's OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot and Moltbot) configuration environment. "This finding marks a significant milestone in the evolution of infostealer behavior: the transition from stealing browser credentials to harvesting the 'souls' and identities of personal AI [
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Study Uncovers 25 Password Recovery Attacks in Major Cloud Password Managers
item.description: A new study has found that multiple cloud-based password managers, including Bitwarden, Dashlane, and LastPass, are susceptible to password recovery attacks under certain conditions. "The attacks range in severity from integrity violations to the complete compromise of all vaults in an organization," researchers Matteo Scarlata, Giovanni Torrisi, Matilda Backendal, and Kenneth G. Paterson said.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Operation DoppelBrand: Weaponizing Fortune 500 Brands
item.description: The GS7 cyber-threat group targets US financial institutions with near-perfect imitations of corporate portals to steal credentials and gain remote access.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Vulnerabilities in Password Managers Allow Hackers to View and Change Passwords
item.description: Security researchers have challenged end-to-end encryption claims from popular commercial password managers

item.title: Fake ‘Antivirus’ App Spreads Android Malware, Steals Banking Credentials
item.description: <p>A fake Android antivirus app called TrustBastion is spreading malware and stealing banking credentials. Here’s how it works and how to stay protected.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-fake-android-antivirus-trustbastion-malware/">Fake &#8216;Antivirus&#8217; App Spreads Android Malware, Steals Banking Credentials</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: SMEs Wrong to Assume They Won’t Be Hit by Cyber-Attacks, NCSC Boss Warns
item.description: NCSC’s Richard Horne has warned that cybercriminals do not care about business size and called for SMEs to act now to secure their organizations

item.title: OysterLoader Evolves With New C2 Infrastructure and Obfuscation
item.description: OysterLoader malware evolves into 2026, refining C2 infrastructure, obfuscation & infection stages

item.title: Operation DoppelBrand Weaponizes Trusted Brands For Credential Theft
item.description: New phishing campaign dubbed Operation DoppelBrand targeted major financial firms like Wells Fargo

item.title: 260K+ Chrome Users Duped by Fake AI Browser Extensions
item.description: 30 copycat apps tricked users, and Google itself, into thinking they're legitimate AI tools.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Weekly Recap: Outlook Add-Ins Hijack, 0-Day Patches, Wormable Botnet & AI Malware
item.description: This week’s recap shows how small gaps are turning into big entry points. Not always through new exploits, often through tools, add-ons, cloud setups, or workflows that people already trust and rarely question. Another signal: attackers are mixing old and new methods. Legacy botnet tactics, modern cloud abuse, AI assistance, and supply-chain exposure are being used side by side, whichever path
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: The Promptware Kill Chain
item.description: <p><a href="https://www.schneier.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/promptware-kill-chain.jpg"><img alt="The promptware kill chain: initial access, privilege escalation, reconnaissance, persistence, command &#38; control, lateral movement, action on objective" src="https://www.schneier.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/promptware-kill-chain-660w.jpg" /></a></p> <p>Attacks against modern generative artificial intelligence (AI) large language models (LLMs) pose a real threat. Yet discussions around these attacks and their potential defenses are dangerously myopic. The dominant narrative focuses on &#8220;<a href="https://simonwillison.net/2022/Sep/12/prompt-injection/">prompt injection</a>,&#8221; a set of techniques to embed instructions into inputs to LLM intended to perform malicious activity. This term suggests a simple, singular vulnerability. This framing obscures a more complex and dangerous reality. Attacks on LLM-based systems have evolved into a distinct class of malware execution mechanisms, which we term &#8220;promptware.&#8221; In a ...</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Safe and Inclusive E‑Society: How Lithuania Is Bracing for AI‑Driven Cyber Fraud
item.description: Technologies are evolving fast, reshaping economies, governance, and daily life. Yet, as innovation accelerates, so do digital risks. Technological change is no longer abstract for such a country as Lithuania, as well. From e-signatures to digital health records, the country depends on secure systems.&nbsp; Cybersecurity has become not only a technical challenge but a societal one – demanding
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Google Warns of In the Wild Exploit as It Patches New Chrome Zero Day
item.description: A high severity vulnerability in Google Chrome and allows remote attackers to execute code

item.title: Crypto Payments to Human Traffickers Surges 85%
item.description: Chainalysis warns that online fraud is fuelling sophisticated human trafficking operations

item.title: New ZeroDayRAT Mobile Spyware Enables Real-Time Surveillance and Data Theft
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new mobile spyware platform dubbed ZeroDayRAT that's being advertised on Telegram as a way to grab sensitive data and facilitate real-time surveillance on Android and iOS devices. "The developer runs dedicated channels for sales, customer support, and regular updates, giving buyers a single point of access to a fully operational spyware
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Odido Breach Impacts Millions of Dutch Telco Users
item.description: Dutch telco Odido has revealed a major data breach impacting over six million customers

item.title: New Chrome Zero-Day (CVE-2026-2441) Under Active Attack — Patch Released
item.description: Google on Friday released security updates for its Chrome browser to address a security flaw that it said has been exploited in the wild. The high-severity vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-2441 (CVSS score: 8.8), has been described as a use-after-free bug in CSS. Security researcher Shaheen Fazim has been credited with discovering and reporting the shortcoming on February 11, 2026. "Use after
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Discloses DNS-Based ClickFix Attack Using Nslookup for Malware Staging
item.description: Microsoft has disclosed details of a new version of the ClickFix social engineering tactic in which the attackers trick unsuspecting users into running commands that carry out a Domain Name System (DNS) lookup to retrieve the next-stage payload. Specifically, the attack relies on using the "nslookup" (short for nameserver lookup) command to execute a custom DNS lookup triggered via the Windows
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Upcoming Speaking Engagements
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Viral AI Caricatures Highlight Shadow AI Dangers
item.description: <p>A viral AI caricature trend may be exposing sensitive enterprise data, fueling shadow AI risks, social engineering attacks, and LLM account compromise.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-ai-caricature-trend-shadow-ai-security-risks/">Viral AI Caricatures Highlight Shadow AI Dangers</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.description: Zscaler's acquisition of SquareX comes as competitors like CrowdStrike and Palo Alto Networks also invest in secure browser technologies.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Schwartz

item.title: Google Ties Suspected Russian Actor to CANFAIL Malware Attacks on Ukrainian Orgs
item.description: A previously undocumented threat actor has been attributed to attacks targeting Ukrainian organizations with malware known as CANFAIL. Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) described the hacking group as possibly affiliated with Russian intelligence services. The threat actor is assessed to have targeted defense, military, government, and energy organizations within the Ukrainian regional and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Under Pressure to Bolster Defenses for BYOVD Attacks
item.description: Threat actors are exploiting security gaps to weaponize Windows drivers and terminate security processes in targeted networks, and there may be no easy fixes in sight.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Nation-State Hackers Put Defense Industrial Base Under Siege
item.description: Espionage groups from China, Russia and other nations burned at least two dozen zero-days in edge devices in attempts to infiltrate defense contractors' networks.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: AI Agents 'Swarm,' Security Complexity Follows Suit
item.description: As AI deployments scale and start to include packs of agents autonomously working in concert, organizations face a naturally amplified attack surface.

item.title: Google Links China, Iran, Russia, North Korea to Coordinated Defense Sector Cyber Operations
item.description: Several state-sponsored actors, hacktivist entities, and criminal groups from China, Iran, North Korea, and Russia have trained their sights on the defense industrial base (DIB) sector, according to findings from Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG). The tech giant's threat intelligence division said the adversarial targeting of the sector is centered around four key themes: striking defense
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Ransomware Groups Claimed 2,000 Attacks in Just Three Months
item.description: <p>Ransomware attacks surged 52% in 2025, with supply chain breaches nearly doubling as groups like Qilin drive record monthly incidents worldwide.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-ransomware-attacks-surge-2025/">Ransomware Groups Claimed 2,000 Attacks in Just Three Months</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: UAT-9921 Deploys VoidLink Malware to Target Technology and Financial Sectors
item.description: A previously unknown threat actor tracked as UAT-9921 has been observed leveraging a new modular framework called VoidLink in its campaigns targeting the technology and financial services sectors, according to findings from Cisco Talos. "This threat actor seems to have been active since 2019, although they have not necessarily used VoidLink over the duration of their activity," researchers Nick
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Munich Security Conference: Cyber Threats Lead G7 Risk Index, Disinformation Ranks Third
item.description: G7 countries ranked cyber-attacks as the top risk, while BICS members placed cyber threats only as the eighth most pressing risk

item.title: Malicious Chrome Extensions Caught Stealing Business Data, Emails, and Browsing History
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a malicious Google Chrome extension that's designed to steal data associated with Meta Business Suite and Facebook Business Manager. The extension, named CL Suite by @CLMasters (ID: jkphinfhmfkckkcnifhjiplhfoiefffl), is marketed as a way to scrape Meta Business Suite data, remove verification pop-ups, and generate two-factor authentication (2FA) codes.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Fake AI Assistants in Google Chrome Web Store Steal Passwords and Spy on Emails
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of users have downloaded malicious AI extensions masquerading as ChatGPT, Gemini, Grok and others, warn cybersecurity researchers at LayerX

item.title: npm’s Update to Harden Their Supply Chain, and Points to Consider
item.description: In December 2025, in response to the Sha1-Hulud incident, npm completed a major authentication overhaul intended to reduce supply-chain attacks. While the overhaul is a solid step forward, the changes don’t make npm projects immune from supply-chain attacks. npm is still susceptible to malware attacks – here’s what you need to know for a safer Node community. Let’s start with the original
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Researchers Observe In-the-Wild Exploitation of BeyondTrust CVSS 9.9 Vulnerability
item.description: Threat actors have started to exploit a recently disclosed critical security flaw impacting BeyondTrust Remote Support (RS) and Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products, according to watchTowr. "Overnight we observed first in-the-wild exploitation of BeyondTrust across our global sensors," Ryan Dewhurst, head of threat intelligence at watchTowr, said in a post on X. "Attackers are abusing
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Ivanti EPMM Zero-Day Bugs Spark Exploit Frenzy — Again
item.description: It's time to phase out the &quot;patch and pray&quot; approach, eliminate needless public interfaces, and enforce authentication controls, one expert says.

item.title: Critical Apple Flaw Exploited in ‘Sophisticated’ Attacks, Company Urges Rapid Patching
item.description: <p>Apple urges users to update after patching CVE-2026-20700, a zero-day flaw exploited in sophisticated targeted attacks across multiple devices.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-apple-zero-day-cve-update-february-2026/">Critical Apple Flaw Exploited in ‘Sophisticated’ Attacks, Company Urges Rapid Patching</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: Booz Allen Announces General Availability of Vellox Reverser to Automate Malware Defense
item.description: The AI-powered product delivers expert-grade malware analysis and reverse engineering in minutes.

item.title: SpecterOps Launches BloodHound Scentry to Accelerate the Practice of Identity Attack Path Management
item.description: Drawing on years of adversary tradecraft, SpecterOps experts work alongside customers to analyze and eliminate attack paths, protect critical assets, and stay ahead of emerging threats.

item.title: Gone With the Shame: One in Two Americans Are Reluctant to Talk About Romance Scam Incidents
item.description: Men should take extra care on Valentine’s Day because they are nearly twice as likely as women to fall victim to romance scams.

item.title: Those 'Summarize With AI' Buttons May Be Lying to You
item.description: Microsoft uncovered AI recommendation poisoning in 31 companies across 14 industries, and turnkey tools make it trivially easy to pull off.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Microsoft’s February Patch Tuesday Fixes 6 Zero-Days Under Attack
item.description: <p>Microsoft patches 58 vulnerabilities, including six actively exploited zero-days across Windows, Office, and RDP, as CISA sets a March 3 deadline.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-patch-tuesday-six-zero-days-february-2026/">Microsoft’s February Patch Tuesday Fixes 6 Zero-Days Under Attack</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Aminu Abdullahi

item.title: Google Reports State-Backed Hackers Using Gemini AI for Recon and Attack Support
item.description: Google on Thursday said it observed the North Korea-linked threat actor known as UNC2970 using its generative artificial intelligence (AI) model Gemini to conduct reconnaissance on its targets, as various hacking groups continue to weaponize the tool for accelerating various phases of the cyber attack life cycle, enabling information operations, and even conducting model extraction attacks. "The
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Lazarus Campaign Plants Malicious Packages in npm and PyPI Ecosystems
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Proofpoint Expands AI Security Offerings With Acuvity Acquisition
Proofpoint acquires Acuvity to tackle the security risks of agentic AI
World Leaks Ransomware Group Adds Stealthy, Custom Malware ‘RustyRocket’ to Attacks
item.description: Accenture Cybersecurity warns over difficult to detect, “sophisticated toolset” being deployed as part of extortion campaigns

item.title: Nation-State Hackers Embrace Gemini AI for Malicious Campaigns, Google Finds
item.description: Google researchers found that government-backed hackers now use AI throughout the whole attack lifecycle

item.title: 3D Printer Surveillance
item.description: <p>New York is <a href="https://blog.adafruit.com/2026/02/03/new-york-wants-to-ctrlaltdelete-your-3d-printer/">contemplating</a> a bill that adds surveillance to 3D printers:</p> <blockquote><p>New York’s 2026­2027 executive budget bill (S.9005 / A.10005) includes language that should alarm every maker, educator, and small manufacturer in the state. Buried in Part C is a provision requiring all 3D printers sold or delivered in New York to include &#8220;blocking technology.&#8221; This is defined as software or firmware that <i>scans every print file</i> through a &#8220;firearms blueprint detection algorithm&#8221; and refuses to print anything it flags as a potential firearm or firearm component...</i></p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: AI Prompt RCE, Claude 0-Click, RenEngine Loader, Auto 0-Days & 25+ Stories
item.description: Threat activity this week shows one consistent signal — attackers are leaning harder on what already works. Instead of flashy new exploits, many operations are built around quiet misuse of trusted tools, familiar workflows, and overlooked exposures that sit in plain sight. Another shift is how access is gained versus how it’s used. Initial entry points are getting simpler, while post-compromise
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI Skills Represent Dangerous New Attack Surface, Says TrendAI
item.description: New TrendAI report warns that most security tools can’t protect against attacks on AI skills artifacts

item.title: The CTEM Divide: Why 84% of Security Programs Are Falling Behind
item.description: A new 2026 market intelligence study of 128 enterprise security decision-makers (available here) reveals a stark divide forming between organizations – one that has nothing to do with budget size or industry and everything to do with a single framework decision. Organizations implementing Continuous Threat Exposure Management (CTEM) demonstrate 50% better attack surface visibility, 23-point
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Naming and shaming: How ransomware groups tighten the screws on victims
item.description: When corporate data is exposed on a dedicated leak site, the consequences linger long after the attack fades from the news cycle

item.title: Time to Exploit Plummets as N-Day Flaws Dominate
item.description: Flashpoint warns of a dramatic drop in the average time between vulnerability disclosure and exploitation

item.title: Senegalese Data Breaches Expose Lack of Security Maturity
item.description: Green Blood Group steals personal records and biometric data of the West African nation's nearly 20 million residents.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: 83% of Ivanti EPMM Exploits Linked to Single IP on Bulletproof Hosting Infrastructure
item.description: A significant chunk of the exploitation attempts targeting a newly disclosed security flaw in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) can be traced back to a single IP address on bulletproof hosting infrastructure offered by PROSPERO. Threat intelligence firm GreyNoise said it recorded 417 exploitation sessions from 8 unique source IP addresses between February 1 and 9, 2026. An estimated 346
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
